Title: Benedict Cumberbatch Hoping To Adapt Classic British Novel ‘Rogue Male' Next Year
Description:
By Jake Kanter 

International Investigations Editor


Benedict Cumberbatch has confirmed that he remains committed to adapting Rogue Male, the classic British novel that he says inspired Ian Fleming to write James Bond.


	Cumberbatch and his production company SunnyMarch announced in 2016 that they planned to adapt Geoffrey Household's book, but the feature film has yet to get off the ground. 


	Speaking on the SmartLess podcast, hosted by Sean Hayes, Jason Bateman, and Will Arnett, Cumberbatch said he hoped to slate the shoot for 2026.


	He warned, however, that “there are other huge commitments involving cloaks floating about,” which appeared to be confirmation that he is reprising his role as Doctor Strange in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

	











	
	
		
					Related Stories		
	













	News
	



	
		
					Miles Teller Blames "One Really Important Person" On 'Fantastic Four' For "F***ing It All Up"		
			















	News
	



	
		
					Elizabeth Olsen Says She's "Excited To See" Marvel's 'VisionQuest': "It Really Sounds Like A Trifecta"		
			








	“We haven't got a filming date yet, but it's something we're trying to slate for next year,” Cumberbatch said. “We will make it, definitely.” 




			Watch on Deadline		







	Published in 1939, Rogue Male follows an unnamed English sportsman who attempts to assassinate a European dictator, strongly implied to be Adolf Hitler. He is caught, tortured and left for dead, but escapes back to England, where he hides out in the countryside with enemy agents and police in pursuit.


	“It's the original fugitive novel and a huge inspiration for Ian Fleming for Bond,” Cumberbatch continued. “When we first sat down to talk about this, [we thought] is this a bit of a guy's film? 


	“The longer we were exploring the themes of it and the motivation behind the guy's actions, and the outcome, and how he's turned on by his own side, as well as the side he's tried to take down, it's fascinating how it plays into the political spectrum of what's going on in the world right now.”

	











	When the project was first announced, Michael Lesslie (Macbeth, Assassin's Creed) was hired to write the screenplay. It was set up at Fox Searchlight, and Cumberbatch was slated to star.


	Peter O'Toole appeared in a BBC adaptation of Rogue Male made for television in 1977. Twentieth Century Fox adapted the novel in 1940 as Man Hunt.

Title: Xochitl Gomez claims she's 'single' — but fuels Robert Irwin dating speculation with pointed social media move
Description:
Xochitl Gomez claims she's “single” — but fueled speculation she's dating Robert Irwin with a pointed social media move.

During Tuesday night's finale of “Dancing With the Stars” Season 34, which saw Irwin win the dance competition, Gomez, who won Season 32, was asked in an interview with “DWTS” pro Jan Ravnik whether she's “single.”

Giggling, the actress insisted, “Yes, I am. I am. Yes, I am.”

Advertisement

Advertisement

However, on Wednesday, she took to Instagram to post a carousel from finale night.

“What a season! Congratulations to all the finalists ♥️🪩🫂,” Gomez, 19, captioned the photos, which included a cozy close-up shot with Irwin, 21.

Gomez concluded her slideshow with a picture of a much-younger Irwin holding the Len Goodman Mirrorball Trophy his older sister, Bindi Irwin, won in 2015's “DWTS” Season 21.

“The last picture though,” he commented.

Advertisement

Robert, for his part, hasn't done much to dispel the romance rumors, which sparked after he and Gomez displayed undeniable chemistry while performing on “DWTS” together earlier this month. (The show's current contestants were paired with past champions for a dance relay.)

“Everyone's asking if you and Xochitl are an item!” a TMZ paparazzo said to Robert as he arrived for practice.

Advertisement

Swerving the question, the wildlife conservationist replied, “Oh, my gosh. We had the best time! That dance was so much fun.”


							Sign up for Virtual Reali-Tea with Danny and Evan, our must-read newsletter!						




						Please provide a valid email.					



				By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.			


					Want more celebrity and pop culture news?				

He marveled at the energetic routine, going on to gush that “she's the best.”

Asked once again whether the pair are “an item or just friends,” Robert smiled and walked into the studio.

Then ahead of Tuesday's show, Gomez was photographed paying the zookeeper a private visit outside his trailer.

Advertisement

The “Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness” star presented Robert with a massive bouquet of flowers, gave him an affectionate side hug and laughed as she chatted with him.

Advertisement

After the seemingly flirty exchange, a source told Page Six that the duo have been enjoying each other's company since connecting through the dance competition.

“They are having a lot of fun. They're both extroverts with a lot of energy,” the source said, calling Gomez “the sweetest person.”

Title: TikTok Star With 6.9M Followers Passes Away at 24
Description:
Beloved TikTok star Marquay Collins, known online as “Marquay the Goat,” has passed away.

The content creator, who was famous for his lifestyle and comedy videos, died at age 24, per PEOPLE.

Collins's mother, Sonja, announced the heartbreaking news on Facebook on November 26.

“My heart is broken. My baby, my last one, my SnuggaBug, my Marquay is no longer here with me,” Sonja captioned a photo of them together. “He was the sweetest person. He didn't have a mean bone in his body. I needed him longer than God allowed me to have him. He spoiled me and his Dad, Elzie, he always said, because we spoiled him. Thank you everyone, for your thoughts and prayers. Enjoy the rest of your day.”

The cause of Collins's death has not yet been disclosed.

Collins's passing shocked many of his followers, prompting an outpouring of sadness and condolences in the comment section.

One fan wrote, “My heart is broken right now. The life of the party is gone. I'm always watching you on TikTok.”

Another commented, “Don't worry Marquay! HEAVEN GOT A PLAN FOR YOU. Prayers up!”

Someone pointed out, “He posted 16 hours ago and now gone. Life can change in a split second. RIP young man.”

A fan added, “A reminder how life is so short. One day you're here and the next day you're gone.”

Many also expressed their disbelief that Collins had passed away. A fan asked, “It's just a rumor right?”

Another wrote, “They saying you gone… say it's a joke pls,” while someone chimed in, “Tell me it isn't true bro.”

Collins has a massive following of over 6.9 million on TikTok and is still counting. His last post on the platform was on November 25.

Replying to @So Local I needed that! #xyzbca #fyp #lotion 

The online community lost several social media influencers in 2025. Before the year ends, here are some of the beloved online stars who were gone too soon.

Hailey Okula, a nursing influencer, passed away after giving birth to her first child. She was 33.

Rodeo Queen influencer Camila Trevisol died at 33 after a battle with a rare form of bone cancer.

Filipino TikTok star Emman Atienza passed away in October at age 19.

Another Filipino influencer and model, Gina Lima, was pronounced dead in November after she was taken to the hospital by her ex-boyfriend, Ivan Cezar Ronquillo. Three days later, Ronquillo was found dead in what authorities suspect was a suicide.

Food influencer Michael Duarte passed away after getting into a “horrible accident.”

TikTok influencer Kaelin Bradshaw succumbed to stage 4 Cholangiocarcinoma cancer in October. Fellow TikToker Jacinda Jenkins died unexpectedly in September at 28 years old.

Title: Every Taylor Sheridan Show, Ranked: A Skeptic and a Believer Debate the Best and Worst
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

The best Taylor Sheridan shows have accumulated their loyal, and large, followings for fairly obvious reasons: They're just damn good. The 55-year-old actor turned writer-producer knows how to write compelling characters and play them off each other in distinctive settings. And he has a knack for channeling and showing off star power, whether it's Sylvester Stallone in “Tulsa King,” Harrison Ford and Helen Mirren in “1923,” or Billy Bob Thornton in “Landman.”

But stretching his empire into eight series has resulted in a feeling that Sheridan has spread himself a little too thin as a writer, and more recent seasons of his shows have shown the signs of a creator pulled in a few too many directions. Notorious for flying solo and exerting tremendous control over his projects, Sheridan's said he's usually on set during the week and then writes an entire episode of one of his shows on Saturdays — all fueled by regular B-12 shots, of course.

Sheridan might do well to value quality over quantity a bit more, and perhaps, with the shrinkage of the streaming ecosystem and his departure from Paramount for NBCUniversal, he'll have an opportunity to reset. Ranking Taylor Sheridan's shows is not massively difficult because there are some that clearly stand out and others that sink to the bottom. Though exactly which is which is up for some debate, so that's exactly what we've done. 

IndieWire Digital Director Christian Blauvelt is an admirer of Sheridan and appreciative of his work. He thinks it's impressive what an actor who had a bit part in “Star Trek: Enterprise” and played a villain on “Veronica Mars” has achieved as a creator, while mostly maintaining a respectable level of quality. Head TV Critic Ben Travers is more of a skeptic — he certainly doesn't agree that Sheridan's success stems from great writing (great casting seems more likely, plus a convenient dearth of prestige-flavored westerns) — and he's only found one or two of Sheridan's shows worthy of weekly viewing.

Who's right? Who's wrong? And what shows are worth your time? We'll let you decide.

IndieWire's list of Taylor Sheridan's shows, ranked from best to worst, is below.

Ben Travers: Not to overextend whatever credit I have as our resident “hater,” but “Tulsa King” is my preferred Taylor Sheridan show because it's the least like all of Taylor Sheridan's other shows. The first season is funny! The episodes hum! The main characters actually like each other! “Tulsa King” is about a rag-tag group of outcasts who try to build something together, rather than a haunted family who fights all the time as their long-sullied legacy falls apart. Which one of those options sounds better to you?

For Sheridan, it's not “Tulsa King.” Despite sky-high viewership, the creator (whose work on the series ended when he co-wrote the pilot) wasn't pleased with the first season and tried to oust the showrunner, Terence Winter (“Boardwalk Empire”). Thankfully, Winter made his way back to the fray (off and on), and “Tulsa King” was able to preserve parts of its original tone, while still getting Sylvester Stallone's hands dirty enough to fit in with Sheridan's other tough guys. 

Is it perfect? No. It's far from the best of either writer (Winter or Stallone), and there's certainly a more serious crime drama stirring somewhere within this silly one. But when so many of Sheridan's shows feel like medieval torture chambers (misery, violence, more misery), I'm going to savor whatever time I can get with a kingly court jester.

Christian Blauvelt: The turn away from miserabilism that “Tulsa King” represents for Sheridan is a welcome one, though I can't help think that this “crime comedy” series gets a little too silly for its own good on many occasions. And I wonder how much it would hold together at all if not for the star power of Stallone at its center. I also think that the show gets better once Sheridan left: I found the early part of Season 1 to be kind of a tract-in-show-form where Sheridan could spew his anti-woke sentiments without necessarily giving them much dramatic structure. It was annoying. I found those early eps to be as performatively about the “culture wars” as anything Sheridan has ever done, and given an added degree of inauthenticity because it feels at times that he's really a lefty just dressed in MAGA clothing.

Similarly, I found that some of the culture warrior things he said on “The Joe Rogan Experience” ended up verbatim in “Lioness” Season 2. More on that in the “Lioness” blurb, but yes, this is where I can acknowledge that I was so high on the Sheridan-verse I literally listened to his entire three-hour-plus Joe Rogan podcast, which was another reminder about what a terrible interviewer Rogan is and a massive missed opportunity given how few interviews Sheridan grants. Anyway, once “Tulsa King” actually became a show about its characters rather than making a point to ruffle PC sensibilities it became the fun romp you describe. Is it churlish to say that Sheridan's best show is one he barely had involvement with after its beginning? Of course. But though we are not here to bury Sheridan, we can certainly be clear-eyed about the limitations of his work as well.

Christian: I mean, if any series brings tears to my eyes for the entire final episode that has to be a massive success, and for me “1883” is in every sense Sheridan's most perfectly formed show. This is the rare 10-episode series that actually does feel like a 10-hour movie, one devoid of flab and filler but that also never puts plot before character even as it's exquisitely plotted.

A wagon-train Western for the ages, “1883” gives us our chronological first glimpse of the Dutton family as an impoverished first-generation Irish clan in Tennessee heading to parts West for a better life. Yes, it focuses on the trip's grind and misery, but not for the sake of miserabilism; more to establish real stakes, meaning, and purpose. It takes five episodes just for the wagon train to get out of Texas, and though that may be partly due to Sheridan being able to film that much more on his Texas ranch, it emphasizes what those seeking a better life in the West were willing to endure – largely on foot. And like any immigrant story, there's something incredibly hopeful at its core — a hope that justifies the grind.

This is also one of the only Westerns other than “Heaven's Gate” to delve deep into the extraordinary diversity of those heading West — that they were very often immigrants from Germany, Sweden, Poland, the Balkans, and all over Eastern Europe, including persecuted Roma. Like “Heaven's Gate,” there isn't much English dialogue you hear from these characters and “1883” focuses on the misunderstandings that arise simply from the language barrier.

Sheridan's writing of women can also be very bad across his work… and yet, he delivered the single most complex characterization of his entire writing career in Elsa (Isabel May), whose poetic narration anchors the series. There's also a reason why Sam Elliott got the most prominent acting award ever for a Sheridan show for his work on “1883” — a SAG Award for Best Actor in a Miniseries. As a classic Western gunslinger who suffers the loss of his entire family from smallpox before deciding to embark on one last journey to the Pacific as a wagon train boss, he ends up tugging at your heartstrings like no one else.

Ben: Well, what you find poetic I find grating. Elsa's narration is a crutch, and her observations are too often vague platitudes that betray the insight she should have as a storyteller who knows the whole narrative.

To that end, “1883” may acknowledge the American melting pot as it spills out across the plains, but its perspective remains rooted in a white family, which makes it familiar and limited. Women characters rank second only to Native Americans when it comes to Sheridan's vexing portrayals, and “1883” doesn't exactly work to acknowledge the ways in which the country's original settlers built a functioning society. That may not be fair to the story it does tell — with passion, earnestness, and ambition — but it's a historical fact that seems to butt against the writer's preferred American origin story. (And it makes his sadistic streak harder to stomach when the pioneers start dying off in disparate droves.)

Elsewhere, James and Margaret Dutton (Tim McGraw and Faith Hill, respectively) don't do much for me as protagonists (or performers), which elevates Elliott's work almost by default. (I say almost because he is quite affecting, even if that SAG Award Actors Award should've gone to Steve Carell for “The Patient.”) Perhaps if “1883” weren't tied to “Yellowstone” — if it had been a true standalone project — some of these slights may have softened. But as it is, I still feel them.

Christian: What's so invigorating about “1923” Season 1 is how much Sheridan works in pure adventure mode. It's not miserabilism for miserabilism's sake, even in the repeated, brutal beatings suffered by Aminah Nieves' Teonna, an Indigenous girl forced to live in an abusive Catholic boarding school. That misery has a point: to illuminate a particular injustice rarely shown before on American screens. And of course, it's all to set up a thrilling, cross-country revenge story for Teonna, which becomes the best part of Season 2 — maybe the only genuinely satisfying part of Season 2, when all is said and done.

Yes, this show fizzles a bit by the end of its 16-episode run, and it's hard not to think that it would have been better served with less. But there's no storyline more purely fun and exciting in Sheridan's canon than that of big game hunter Spencer Dutton (Brandon Sklenar, in a breakout performance for the ages) finding romance with runaway British royal Alexandra (Julia Schlaepfer) on the East African savannah. Together, they're menaced by lions, sharks, and a consumptive tugboat captain trying to ferry them to Suez when Spencer gets the call to return to Montana lest his family empire be overrun by a mustache-twirling Timothy Dalton.

Here, Sheridan thinks in terms of images for his storytelling in a way he doesn't always: When Spencer and Alexandra are adrift on the high seas following the aforementioned tugboat captain's death, they run afoul of an abandoned ocean liner “ghost ship” that causes them to wreck as well. A couple episodes later, after they're rescued, Alex runs afoul of the aristocrats who tried to force her into a loveless marriage and a shipboard duel with Spencer wearing a tux ensues. All of this is the kind of spectacle that even most big-screen entertainments haven't offered in years, and it's Sheridan making the absolute most of Paramount's budget-largesse at the time. The money is on the screen.

Unfortunately, Season 2, with the exception of Teonna's revenge arc, does see Sheridan slipping back into his miserabilist tendencies. There's a godawful storyline where Dalton's land baron endlessly engages in sadomasochistic sex with two sex workers he's hired and is trying to turn against each other: Yes, it's trying to make a point about the entanglement of economic power and sexual abuse, but the point is established early and its continued elaboration calls into question Sheridan's own motives. There are still some great moments here and there — Spencer running afoul of evil hobos when hitching a ride on a boxcar and him freeing a tarred-and-feathered sex worker from a puritanical mob in Fort Worth come to mind — but the series ends on a note of such anguish that I can't ever imagine watching “1923” again. “1883” ends tragically but feels earned (rather than just it being “Oh, let's put our audience through as much agony as possible”). This show, however, hooks you with adventure and romance and a gripping revenge plot only to leave you totally shattered.

Ben: You've done most of my hater work for me, Christian, so I'll just say Harrison Ford does a lot to make this grim western tolerable. In a rare cowboy role for the movie star, Ford's Jacob Dutton sports a perpetual grimace that's softened by our decades of affection for the actor himself. I don't know if I'd go as far as to say Sheridan relies on that endearing quality — he's going to tell his story, his way, no matter who's in the saddle — but it's certainly helpful to his audience. There's just something about that face, no matter what horrors it witnesses or perpetuates, that triggers your humanity.

Ben: “Yellowstone” aside (kind of), Taylor Sheridan doesn't exactly have an established track record when it comes to creating sustainable TV series. That makes sense, to a degree, given he started in movies (and still often writes like he's making movies). But between “1883” (limited series), “Bass Reeves” (canceled after one season), and the relative infancy of his other “hit” shows, it's worth wondering whether any of his TV ideas are built to last. (Even “Tulsa King,” which is about to shoot its fourth season, has faced production issues every year! Season 4 doesn't even have a showrunner!)

So the nicest thing I can say about “Mayor of Kingstown” is that it's proven it can go the distance. Relying on its star “Avenger” (if not a star “Avenger”) and a premiere episode twist straight out of “Game of Thrones,” the dark-and-gritty Michigan crime drama has produced four seasons in five years, all of which star Jeremy Renner's ex-con turned unofficial warden of a prison (Kings)town, Mike McLusky. Along the way, it's employed legends like Dianne Wiest and Edie Falco to bring emotional nuance to a series mired in merciless pain. It's antihero show in an age that's moved on from antiheroes, but hey, at least it's a legitimate show!

Christian: It is an antihero show in an age of that's moved on from antiheroes — though I would argue that the Duttons in “Yellowstone” have basically become a crime family by that point, unlike their noble presentation in “1883” and “1923” — but the reason for that may also be that “Mayor of Kingstown” was the first series Sheridan wrote even though it wasn't the first to air. So it strangely has a whiff of the mid-2010s in many respects.

I think this is peak middle-of-the-road Sheridan. Not particularly memorable, but, as you've said, oddly sustainable? This is probably the closest he comes to the CBS or TNT model of shows that people watch for years on end but that don't in any way move the culture.

Ben: Ah, “Yellowstone.” The unexpected hit that became the backbone of an entire network (and then its streamer, and then, come 2029, another streamer). The Kevin Costner-starring Western certainly benefited from his star power, helping to lure an audience eager for the sweeping American grandeur captured in “Dances with Wolves” and the next iteration of iconic cowboys glimpsed in “Silverado,” “Wyatt Earp,” and “Open Range.”

While Sheridan's breakthrough series certainly delivered on those fronts — John Dutton's existential battle against progress, time, and death itself proved to be the series' most arresting conflict, which was only emphasized by Sheridan's many, many, many montages of cowboys riding across the ranch's purple mountain majesty — the behind-the-scenes battles between “Yellowstone's” principal patriarchs ruined a delayed, extended, and ultimately nonsensical final season.

And when I say “ruined,” I mean the best of “Yellowstone” fell to Earth alongside its omnipresent worst traits: uneven pacing, clichéd, redundant character development, and a brutal streak that made scenes too silly to take seriously and too nasty to savor. Even for those who thought parts of “Yellowstone” were worthy of the awards love that never came, the ending emphasized exactly why Sheridan's first TV series deserved exactly what it got: big ratings, little relevance.

Christian: I do agree that the way “Yellowstone” ended was so disastrous it mars the entire show — to me it's far worse than what happened with the “Lost” or “Game of Thrones” finales, and there's part of me that thinks “Yellowstone” should be ranked last here as a result. Especially since “1883” and “1923” do so many more interesting things with this kind of material. “Yellowstone” is, above all, a ridiculous soap opera.

That said, there are times throughout its run that you can see very clearly why it became such a phenomenon, and I think part of it is due to its pacing: This could be as languid a series as any on TV, one largely about character rather than plot (which is why the plot-heavy contortions of its final season are such a betrayal). This is a show where you suddenly could have Gil Birmingham giving a long monologue about the relationship between men and wolves, and how each exist to keep the population of the other in check — several minutes in, I let out an audible “This is great.” 

Same goes for the frequent musical performances (only Cheo Hodari Coker's “Luke Cage” in recent vintage embraced putting plot on the skids like this) and “hangout moments” with the cowboys in the bunk house. “Yellowstone” worked best when it was a mood, a vibe. Having Sheridan himself appear as a sex-god horse trader who counts Bella Hadid as his girlfriend actually contributed to that vibe. Having the endless mean-spiritedness of Jamie (Wes Bentley) and Beth (Kelly Reilly) curdle into conspiracy nonsense and an ultimate knife fight very much did not.

Christian: I personally would rank “Lawmen: Bass Reeves” much higher on this list and I protest Ben's placement of it here! This is one of the most perceptive depictions in American media of that precise moment that Reconstruction transitioned into Jim Crow. And it did so via the first actual historical retelling of a real-life lawman in the Sheridan canon (though the series was created and showrun by Chad Sheehan).

Bass Reeves was a real-life Black lawman who patrolled the Arkansas-Oklahoma border in the 1870s, and the exceptionally gifted David Oyelowo disappeared into this role as effectively as any actor in Sheridan's TV shows. The eight-part series tells an effective story about Reeves going from enslavement to the life of wearing a badge and building a family. It's overarching plot then concerns strange rumors of a “Mr. Sundown” who is spiriting away Black men accused of (often spurious) crimes, and Reeves' investigation has compelling implications for whether slavery ever fully went away or just became the culture of incarceration that's defined American judicial life ever since.

The series is given some of the richest period specificity of any of Sheridan's shows via the extraordinary production design of “Do the Right Thing” and “Malcolm X” legend Wynn Thomas (who just received a richly deserved Honorary Oscar). Did “Bass Reeves” need Dennis Quaid as a wily foil for Reeves? Possibly not. But this is one of the more coherent and fully realized series on this list.

Ben: I gotta say, you're making it sound a whole lot better than it looks. The premiere is a regurgitation of Bass Reeves' Wikipedia page, the legendary lawman's characterization is as broad and accessible as any stock cop on CBS, and the whole show only came to be because Sheridan thought he could fit Reeves into the “Yellowstone” universe, couldn't quite make it work, and then stuck his name on a seasonal anthology that only lasted one season. (They should really change the title from “Lawmen” to “Lawman,” but I guess they're holding out hope for a follow-up.)

Like much of Sheridan's work, it may have good ideas and great production values, but it struggles with the core of great television: characters. I love Oyelowo, and he does his darnedest to liven up a rudimentary historic retelling, but his good-hearted lawman is too disengaged from the world around him. Everyone is too eager to agree with each other and get on with it, whether it's a man of faith conversing with an atheist or an old-school judge and a new-era officer. The series isn't interested in the nuanced internal conflicts that must have roiled inside a former slave who chose to protect and serve slave owners, a Black man forced to fight for the Confederate army, or even a pacifist who picked up a gun every single day. It's interested in tropes. And Bass deserves better.

Christian: One of Sheridan's greatest skills is spotting rising talent to champion: Isabel May in “1883,” Brandon Sklenar in “1923,” and I'd argue Laysla de Oliveira in “Lioness.” The spectrum of material she's asked to play in Season 1 is extraordinary: Stuck in an abusive relationship and working as a fast-food fryer, de Oliveira's Cruz finds a way out when, during a fight with her hateful significant other, she literally stumbles into a Marine recruiting office. And she enlists. It puts her on a journey to becoming a covert operative in the CIA's Lioness division, where certain women agents go undercover in terrorist organizations, drug cartels, and more.

Of Mexican and Syrian heritage, Cruz, who can speak Arabic, is perfect to go undercover inside an Al-Qaeda-style terrorist organization. She's to befriend the daughter of its leader, who, along with her father, leads a luxe life of designer apparel and luxury goods. So Cruz, coming from grinding poverty, has to act accustomed to that life in addition to achieving her mission objectives. I'm not sure there's an actor in any of these shows who's been asked to do more than de Oliveira.

It all boils down to a remarkably critical take on U.S. adventurism abroad, down to the inspired choice of casting “Egyptian Jon Stewart” Bassem Youssef as the amiable terrorist leader. Nicole Kidman as a CIA operative with a disturbingly husky “American” accent does not lend sympathy to the U.S. cause, nor does Zoe Saldana as an operative almost pathologically capable of severing the brutality of her job from her cozy private life. Season 2 then goes in a similar direction, casting a critical eye on the U.S. drug war. It's all full of Sheridan indulgences, including him playing a devil-may-care Special Forces operative who can't keep his shirt on and spouts lines he spoke verbatim about “not being able to have a conversation” about trans issues on “The Joe Rogan Experience.” But working in an “action mode” suits Sheridan, especially as he doesn't indulge in jingoism.

Ben: I'm not sure if I'm fully sold on “Lioness” as a critical take on America's international policy — for all the moral hesitancy over what their missions ultimately accomplish, there's still too much “rah rah” support for the military industrial complex to be seen as a full-on condemnation — but I have to say, as a pure narrative, I find it tremendously dull. The suspense is cheap, the characterizations are clichéd, and the action is hampered because — like way too many Sheridan shows — it's all so freaking dark! 

In the Season 1 finale, it takes more than 40 minutes to pull the pin on the grenade (so to speak), and once they do, the explosion can't even be seen through the black of night. That, and Nicole Kidman gets stuck with one of the worst line readings of her career, while Zoe Saldana barely survives her heated confrontation with the titular lioness. There's something to be said for men sitting and shouting at each other in rooms, stirring up trouble until it nearly starts a war, while the women do the real work outside in the field… but “Lioness” doesn't fit that feminist interpretation, as much as it wants you to believe it can. 

Ben: Before you even get into the ugliness within “Landman's” story, you have to first consider how fundamentally irresponsible it is, even as a piece of fiction. Here's a show so in love with the sound of its own ultra-conservative voice, not only is it happy to prop up the oil industry by spouting lies about clean energy, it's also happy to cash the checks Big Oil throws its way to keep spreading misinformation about why oilfields are the future and wind turbines are for weaklings.

Which brings us to the nauseating nature of the narrative itself. A bitter, hardened story about a bitter, hardened oil lobbyist, the series is built on provocation. Tommy Norris (Billy Bob Thornton) loves to mock anyone and everyone he meets for knowing less than he does. That includes the many… uninformed women populating “Landman” (be it his impetuous ex-wife, his sexed-up daughter, or his “big city” attorney), as well as Tommy's white collar boss and any other authority figure who makes the mistake of knocking on his door. No one measures up to Tommy's standards, and he may like it that way, but it makes for an exhausting viewing experience — who wants to let some old, stuck-up asshole bullshit for hours on end, when he's so sure he knows better than everyone but remains completely oblivious that he's blabbing out of his ass?

It's a testament to Thornton's tough-talking charms that “Landman” is still watchable, just as it's a black mark against Taylor Sheridan that he can't see the tragedy inherent to Tommy's story — a man trapped in the American dream as it rots beneath his feet. Instead, his creator only sees a hero, when by any objective measure, there only stands a fool.

Christian: Sheridan has written some incredible women in these shows: Helen Mirren's Cara in “1923,” Laysla de Oliveira's Cruz in “Lioness,” Aminah Nieves' Teonna in “1923,” and Isabel May's Elsa in “1883” (the single most compelling character he's written, full-stop). Then there's “Landman.” Stephen Rodrick summed it up best in Rolling Stone when he asked of “Landman,” “Why does Jerry Jones have better lines than Demi Moore?” And that's even before considering the unfortunate writing for Ali Larter and Michelle Randolph's characters.

Frankly, much of what I dislike about “Landman” is what similarly rubbed me the wrong way about those early eps of “Tulsa King”: You're right, Ben, that this series is “built on provocation.” It's almost like if Billy Bob Thornton's evil assassin character in the first season of “Fargo” was suddenly given a heroic reframing — Sheridan is all-in on valorizing the petro economy. It speaks to how muddled, perhaps deliberately, his politics are that he can have the entire Dutton franchise be about preserving and respecting the land (and demonizing miners at multiple turns) and then make a show with basically the theme “fuck the environment.” It's also just incredibly wasteful when it comes to its cast: That's what you do with Jon Hamm? Slap a carbon tax on this one.

Title: Scientists Capture Strange Crackling Sounds On Mars
Description:
Unlock more this Holiday Season while supporting the journalism you rely on. For a limited time, new Platinum members can unlock one month free. Support the newsroom that works every day to bring clarity and accountability to the headlines.

Already a member? Log in to hide these messages.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) — Scientists have detected what they believe to be lightning on Mars by eavesdropping on the whirling wind recorded by NASA's Perseverance rover.

The crackling of electrical discharges was captured by a microphone on the rover, a French-led team reported Wednesday.

The researchers documented 55 instances of what they call “mini lightning” over two Martian years, primarily during dust storms and dust devils.

Almost all occurred on the windiest Martian sols, or days, during dust storms and dust devils.

Just inches (centimeters) in size, the electrical arcs occurred within 6 feet (2 meters) of the microphone perched atop the rover's tall mast, part of a system for examining Martian rocks via camera and lasers. Sparks from the electrical discharges — akin to static electricity here on Earth — are clearly audible amid the noisy wind gusts and dust particles smacking the microphone.

Scientists have been looking for electrical activity and lightning at Mars for half a century, said the study's lead author Baptiste Chide, of the Institute for Research in Astrophysics and Planetology in Toulouse.

“It opens a completely new field of investigation for Mars science,” Chide said, citing the possible chemical effects from electrical discharges. “It's like finding a missing piece of the puzzle.”

The evidence is strong and persuasive, but it's based on a single instrument that was meant to record the rover zapping rocks with lasers, not lightning blasts, said Cardiff University's Daniel Mitchard, who was not involved in the study. What's more, he noted in an article accompanying the study in the journal Nature, the electrical discharges were heard — not seen.

“It really is a chance discovery to hear something else going on nearby, and everything points to this being Martian lightning,” Mitchard said in an email. But until new instruments are sent to verify the findings, “I think there will still be a debate from some scientists as to whether this really was lightning.”

Lightning has already been confirmed on Jupiter and Saturn, and Mars has long been suspected of having it too.

To find it, Chide and his team analyzed 28 hours of Perseverance recordings, documenting episodes of “mini lightning” based on acoustic and electric signals.

Electrical discharges generated by the fast-moving dust devils lasted just a few seconds, while those spawned by dust storms lingered as long as 30 minutes.

“It's like a thunderstorm on Earth, but barely visible with a naked eye and with plenty of faint zaps,” Chide said in an email. He noted that the thin, carbon dioxide-rich Martian atmosphere absorbs much of the sound, making some of the zaps barely perceptible.

Mars' atmosphere is more prone than Earth's to electrical discharging and sparking through contact among grains of dust and sand, according to Chide.

“The current evidence suggests it is extremely unlikely that the first person to walk on Mars could, as they plant a flag on the surface, be struck down by a bolt of lightning,” Mitchard wrote in Nature. But the “small and frequent static-like discharges could prove problematic for sensitive equipment.”

These aren't the first Mars sounds transmitted by Perseverance. Earthlings have listened in to the rover's wheels crunching over the Martian surface and the whirring blades of its no-longer-flying helicopter sidekick, Ingenuity.

Perseverance has been scouring a dry river delta at Mars since 2021, collecting samples of rock for possible signs of ancient microscopic life. NASA plans to return these core samples to Earth for laboratory analysis, but the delivery is on indefinite hold as the space agency pursues cheaper options.

The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Department of Science Education and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The AP is solely responsible for all content.

Title: Tourist dies after being bitten by shark in Australia
Description:
A tourist believed to be in her 20s has died after being bitten by a shark in Australia on Thursday, according to police.
    


            A man, also believed to be in his 20s, suffered serious injuries in the attack at Crowdy Bay, eastern Australia, and was airlifted to hospital in a critical condition, said New South Wales police in a statement.
    


            Emergency services were called around 6:30 a.m. local time (2:30 p.m. Wednesday ET) following reports that two people had been bitten by a shark, said police.
    


            “Witnesses assisted the pair prior to the arrival of NSW Ambulance paramedics; however, the woman died at the scene,” reads the statement.
    


            Crowdy Bay is about 350 kilometers (217 miles) north of Sydney.
    


            Authorities have not yet determined what species of shark was involved in the attack.
    


            The victims are tourists from Switzerland, a police spokesperson told CNN on Thursday.
    


            Ambulance superintendent Joshua Smyth told journalists that the woman had died by the time paramedics arrived on the scene.
    


            He also praised a bystander who administered first aid to the male victim, including putting a tourniquet around his leg.
    


Rare deadly shark attack sparks ocean hunt in Sydney, Australia



            Smyth said the tourniquet “potentially saved his life and allowed New South Wales Ambulance paramedics to get to him and render first aid.”
    


            Local rescue organization Surf Life Saving NSW said that nearby beaches would be closed for at least 24 hours while they try and find the shark using drones.
    


            “This is a terrible tragedy and our deepest condolences go to the families of the woman and man involved,” said Surf Life Saving NSW CEO Steve Pearce, CNN affiliate 7News reports.
    


            “We have been able to activate our drone capability quickly and have assets on scene to provide surveillance and report on any remaining dangers in the area,” he added.
    


            “For now, please remain clear of the water at beaches in the vicinity and follow the direction of lifeguards.”

Title: Euroclear issues stark warning to EU over Russian assets plot
Description:
The EU could face increased borrowing costs and long-term global reputational damage if it forces through its latest plan to use frozen Russian sovereign assets to finance new loans for Ukraine, Belgian depository Euroclear has warned, according to the Financial Times.

The privately owned clearing house holds around $200 billion of the $300 billion in Russian Central Bank assets frozen in the West after the escalation of the Ukraine conflict in 2022. EU leaders want to issue a ‘reparation loan' to Kiev by using those holdings as collateral. Moscow has denounced any such move as outright theft.

The Brussels-backed plot would be seen globally as “confiscation of central bank reserves, undermining the rule of law” by investors such as sovereign wealth funds and central banks, Euroclear CEO Valerie Urbain has warned, in a letter seen by the FT.

She also warned that the move would make European debt appear riskier and push up government borrowing costs across the bloc for a long time, the paper reported Thursday.

Urbain has previously cautioned that privately owned Euroclear could sue the EU if it attempts to confiscate the Russian sovereign funds held there.

The push to seize Russian assets has intensified as the US promotes a new initiative to settle the Ukraine conflict. US President Donald Trump has expressed optimism that a settlement could be reached. European officials, however, fear the American proposal could complicate the bloc's plans, with the German newspaper Handelsblatt reporting that it might compel the EU to reimburse any diverted Russian funds.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen reaffirmed Brussels' intent to press ahead with the asset grab on Tuesday while pledging continued EU support for Kiev. The Commission insists the proposed scheme does not amount to confiscation, though officials acknowledge there is a risk it will be perceived that way.

Russia has long stated that any attempt to seize its Central Bank assets would be regarded as “theft” and would undermine trust in Western financial institutions. Russian officials have accused Brussels of trying to prolong the Ukraine conflict for political advantage and to justify rising military budgets that benefit European arms manufacturers.

The pattern keeps repeating: Trust vendor → Vendor gets breached → Your users' data exposed. And the cascading effect here is notable - Mixpanel breach → OpenAI API users exposed → Those users likely reused credentials elsewhere.For sensitive operations, the takeaway is clear: minimize what you share with third parties. If your credentials never leave your machine in the first place, they can't be exfiltrated from a vendor breach.The old model of "trust but verify" feels increasingly outdated. The new model probably needs to be "verify or don't share."

Transparency is important to us, so we want to inform you about a recent security incident at Mixpanel, a data analytics provider that OpenAI used for web analytics on the frontend interface for our API product (platform.openai.com). The incident occurred within Mixpanel's systems and involved limited analytics data related to your API account.This was not a breach of OpenAI's systems. No chat, API requests, API usage data, passwords, credentials, API keys, payment details, or government IDs were compromised or exposed.What happened
On November 9, 2025, Mixpanel became aware of an attacker that gained unauthorized access to part of their systems and exported a dataset containing limited customer identifiable information and analytics information. Mixpanel notified OpenAI that they were investigating, and on November 25, 2025, they shared the affected dataset with us.What this means for you
User profile information associated with use of platform.openai.com may have been included in data exported from Mixpanel. The information that may have been affected was limited to:
Name that was provided to us on the API account 
Email address associated with the API account
Approximate coarse location based on API user browser (city, state, country)
Operating system and browser used to access the API account
Referring websites
Organization or User IDs associated with the API account
Our response  
As part of our security investigation, we removed Mixpanel from our production services, reviewed the affected datasets, and are working closely with Mixpanel and other partners to fully understand the incident and its scope. We are in the process of notifying impacted organizations, admins, and users directly. While we have found no evidence of any effect on systems or data outside Mixpanel's environment, we continue to monitor closely for any signs of misuse.Trust, security, and privacy are foundational to our products, our organization, and our mission. We are committed to transparency, and are notifying all impacted customers and users. We also hold our partners and vendors accountable for the highest bar for security and privacy of their services. After reviewing this incident, OpenAI has terminated its use of Mixpanel.Beyond Mixpanel, we are conducting additional and expanded security reviews across our vendor ecosystem and are elevating security requirements for all partners and vendors.What you should keep in mind  
The information that may have been affected here could be used as part of phishing or social engineering attacks against you or your organization.Since names, email addresses, and OpenAI API metadata (e.g., user IDs)  were included, we encourage you to remain vigilant for credible-looking phishing attempts or spam. As a reminder:
Treat unexpected emails or messages with caution, especially if they include links or attachments.
Double-check that any message claiming to be from OpenAI is sent from an official OpenAI domain.
OpenAI does not request passwords, API keys, or verification codes through email, text, or chat.
Further protect your account by enabling multi-factor authentication.
The security and privacy of our products are paramount, and we remain resolute in protecting your information and communicating transparently when issues arise. Thank you for your continued trust in us.For more information about this incident and what it means for impacted users, please see our blog post here.Please contact your account team or mixpanelincident@openai.com if you have any questions or need our support.OpenAI

What happened
On November 9, 2025, Mixpanel became aware of an attacker that gained unauthorized access to part of their systems and exported a dataset containing limited customer identifiable information and analytics information. Mixpanel notified OpenAI that they were investigating, and on November 25, 2025, they shared the affected dataset with us.What this means for you
User profile information associated with use of platform.openai.com may have been included in data exported from Mixpanel. The information that may have been affected was limited to:
Name that was provided to us on the API account 
Email address associated with the API account
Approximate coarse location based on API user browser (city, state, country)
Operating system and browser used to access the API account
Referring websites
Organization or User IDs associated with the API account
Our response  
As part of our security investigation, we removed Mixpanel from our production services, reviewed the affected datasets, and are working closely with Mixpanel and other partners to fully understand the incident and its scope. We are in the process of notifying impacted organizations, admins, and users directly. While we have found no evidence of any effect on systems or data outside Mixpanel's environment, we continue to monitor closely for any signs of misuse.Trust, security, and privacy are foundational to our products, our organization, and our mission. We are committed to transparency, and are notifying all impacted customers and users. We also hold our partners and vendors accountable for the highest bar for security and privacy of their services. After reviewing this incident, OpenAI has terminated its use of Mixpanel.Beyond Mixpanel, we are conducting additional and expanded security reviews across our vendor ecosystem and are elevating security requirements for all partners and vendors.What you should keep in mind  
The information that may have been affected here could be used as part of phishing or social engineering attacks against you or your organization.Since names, email addresses, and OpenAI API metadata (e.g., user IDs)  were included, we encourage you to remain vigilant for credible-looking phishing attempts or spam. As a reminder:
Treat unexpected emails or messages with caution, especially if they include links or attachments.
Double-check that any message claiming to be from OpenAI is sent from an official OpenAI domain.
OpenAI does not request passwords, API keys, or verification codes through email, text, or chat.
Further protect your account by enabling multi-factor authentication.
The security and privacy of our products are paramount, and we remain resolute in protecting your information and communicating transparently when issues arise. Thank you for your continued trust in us.For more information about this incident and what it means for impacted users, please see our blog post here.Please contact your account team or mixpanelincident@openai.com if you have any questions or need our support.OpenAI

The way mixpanel works is that they tag users with a device ID, then once they become a customer, you back port your own customer ID to mix panel and they switch the device ID to your internal customer record so that you can see what your signed up users are doing, where they signed up from and generally track the user journey.

Title: Are Sexual Side Effects Emerging With GLP-1 Agonists?
Description:
Mónica M. Bernardo

 November 27, 2025  

Few new drugs have sparked as much interest and as many questions as GLP-1 agonists. Originally developed to manage blood sugar and support weight loss, these medications are currently being studied for their potential effects on sexual function.

Some patients reported an increase in libido, while others experienced an unexpected decline. The same molecule that regulates glucose may also influence the brain's “pleasure signals.”

Research has shown that these effects on sexual desire vary widely and are shaped by physiologic, psychological, and neurobiological factors. GLP-1 agonists are believed to act on multiple pathways, including the brain's reward system, appetite signals, and sex hormone regulation through metabolic changes.

Available data show that GLP-1 receptor agonists (RAs) mimic endogenous GLP-1 and trigger metabolic effects that may influence sexual health.

A 2025 systematic review and meta-analysis in men with overweight or obesity found that GLP-1 RAs increased total testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone levels, while reducing body weight, BMI, waist circumference, and A1c.

Compared with other antidiabetic or weight-reducing treatments, GLP-1 RAs produced increased gonadotropins and sex hormone-binding globulin and improved erectile function, with serum androgen levels comparable to or exceeding those of other agents. The analysis suggested a potential direct testicular effect, but the primary benefit may be hormonal optimization in men with functional hypogonadism related to excess weight. This hormonal rebalance may translate into improved sexual desire, erectile function, and spermatogenesis.

A 2025 review noted that in men with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and obesity who had erectile dysfunction, GLP-1 RAs improved erectile function, likely via restoration of metabolic and vascular balance essential for the male sexual response.

One year-long study of men with T2D and erectile dysfunction showed that combining metformin with liraglutide or dulaglutide significantly improved International Index of Erectile Function scores, especially in those who lost more weight or had baseline vascular impairment.

However, not all individuals respond similarly. Potential adverse effects may occur in patients with neuroendocrine disorders, preexisting testosterone deficiency, or drug interactions. Rarely do some patients experience reduced sexual desire or erectile function, warranting individualized clinical decisions.

In contrast, in healthy men without metabolic disease, dulaglutide did not significantly affect sexual desire or gonadal hormone levels after 4 weeks.

Evidence in women is limited but includes case reports of sexual dysfunction. One publication described a 71-year-old postmenopausal woman who abruptly developed anorgasmia after starting liraglutide with no hormonal or psychological abnormalities. She reported a loss of clitoral sensitivity and sexual pleasure.

The authors proposed peripheral mechanisms such as reduced genital blood flow and central modulation of dopamine and noradrenaline in brain regions regulating reward and arousal. Nonpharmacologic strategies and sex therapy were ineffective while on liraglutide and switching to semaglutide did not improve the symptoms. However, after transitioning to tirzepatide, the patient regained orgasmic ability, suggesting drug-specific effects.

Another case involved a 36-year-old woman with obesity who developed reduced sexual desire, genital dryness, and anorgasmia after starting tirzepatide. Symptoms resolved after discontinuing treatment and recurred on rechallenge, suggesting medication-related effects. Management included sex therapy, lifestyle modifications, and adjunctive pharmacologic support.

The sexual response in women depends on a complex interplay between estrogen, progesterone, testosterone, and psychosocial factors, complicating the direct attribution to medication.

The leading hypothesis is that GLP-1 RAs modulate dopaminergic reward pathways that regulate hunger, motivation, and satisfaction. Suppression of appetite may also reduce erotic motivation in some patients.

Clinical responses vary widely, with some women reporting increased desire and confidence following weight loss and metabolic improvement.

GLP-1 RAs may influence self-image and social behavior.

A US survey of 2000 single adults found that 59% felt that these medications changed their dating life, and 52% reported changes in their sex life. Within this group, 18% experienced increased sexual desire and 16% reported decreased desire. Men reported improved confidence and attractiveness more frequently than women.

Experts caution that these reports rely on self-reporting, do not distinguish between clinical and cosmetic use, and reflect perceptions rather than confirmed physiologic effects.

Clinicians should proactively address the sexual health of patients treated with GLP-1 RAs. Asking about libido, arousal, and satisfaction can help differentiate medication effects from other causes and guide shared decisions regarding treatment continuation or modification.

This story was translated from El Medico Interactivo, part of the Medscape Professional Network.

Title: What's the best F1 Fantasy line-up for Qatar?
Description:
Authentics

Store

Tickets

Hospitality

Experiences

Previous

Next

Upcoming

'I certainly would've liked to have a 30-point gap instead of 24' - Norris on title challenge

'We'll go all in' - Verstappen aiming to make title fight 'exciting until the end' 

Qatar delivers heat, high-speed cornering and tyre wear that can flip a race upside down. So, who's positioned to thrive at the Lusail International Circuit?

Formula 1 heads to Qatar for one of the most demanding weekends of the season, where sweeping high-speed corners and high temperatures push drivers and machinery to their limits. The Sprint format returns too, giving F1 Fantasy managers another scoring session and more opportunity to change fortunes faster than ever.

With some of the harshest tyre degradation on the calendar, the Qatar Grand Prix places huge emphasis on aero efficiency, tyre management, and drivers who can manage the punishing conditions. Our F1 Fantasy Strategist returns to assess which assets are best equipped to handle the heat as the fight for late-season points reaches boiling point.

Even with only two rounds of the season left, it's never too late to join the free-to-play game and compete for the great prizes on offer every race week! New players will need to select five drivers and two constructors within the starting cost cap of $100 million.

Be sure to join Alpine's Desert Dash mini-league that's taking place over the remaining two rounds of 2025 – the Qatar and Abu Dhabi Grands Prix. There are exciting exclusive prizes on offer, including the winner getting a virtual meet and greet with Pierre Gasly or Franco Colapinto.

Ahead of every Grand Prix weekend, our F1 Fantasy Strategist evaluates seven in-game assets – five drivers and two teams – that can help you succeed in F1 Fantasy, whether that's eking out every point or maximising your budget.

Qatar places a premium on tyre management, aerodynamic efficiency and consistency through long, flowing corners, with the Sprint format amplifying the strategic pressure. Historically, Lusail makes reliable performers and well-balanced cars especially valuable.

Catch up on the Las Vegas Grand Prix highlights below and remember to lock in your teams before the Sprint begins on Saturday, November 29 at 1700 local time (1400 UTC).

McLaren's double disqualification in Las Vegas had significant repercussions in F1 Fantasy and was especially hard-hitting to the 23% of players that owned Lando Norris, who registered a season low -10 fantasy points as a result.

However, this was Norris' first Grand Prix in two seasons where he was not deemed a classified finisher (completing 90% of the race distance) – a remarkable streak of consistency.

The Briton has finished P3 in both Qatar Sprints over the last two seasons and secured a Grand Prix podium, climbing from P10, in 2023.

McLaren have been very competitive in the medium to high-speed corners, for which Lusail has plenty, so expect Norris to be back to his very best as he aims to try and secure his maiden Drivers' Championship.

Las Vegas saw Max Verstappen continue his dominance at high-powered tracks this season, posting his fifth score of 45+ fantasy points in the last seven races while taking his second win in three seasons at the track.

His excellent fantasy form in recent weeks has now propelled the Red Bull racer into first place in the F1 Fantasy driver standings with 675 points on the season.

Verstappen is also the second-best performing driver on Sprint weekends this season, averaging 36.6 fantasy points, just shy of title rival Norris (38.6).

The Dutchman now sits only 24 points adrift of the McLaren racer in the World Drivers' Championship and will require another big result in the desert if he's to continue his remarkable comeback charge – but it's a circuit where he's recorded back-to-back Grand Prix victories.

It has been a campaign of two halves for Carlos Sainz, but his current momentum has him firmly on the right side of his season as it stands.

The Spaniard's 9.9 fantasy points per race weekend and one race retirement is in stark contrast to his 1.5 fantasy points and three Grand Prix retirements through the first 14 weekends of the season.

His most recent highlight was a P3 Qualifying result in Las Vegas, on his way to a 16-point haul for fantasy owners last time out.

Requiring a mere -5 fantasy points for a $0.6m price rise, Sainz's recent form suggests he should be excellently positioned to achieve this with another strong showing.

Back-to-back double-digit fantasy scores lands Isack Hadjar back on the Strategist's watchlist for Qatar.

His 16-point return in Las Vegas tied his second-highest score in 2025, while extending his classified finishing streak to 10 races.

The Racing Bulls rookie added to his Q3 record last weekend too, notching his 13th appearance in 22 Qualifying sessions this campaign – the best among all drivers not racing for a top-four outfit in the Teams' Championship.

If Hadjar can continue this trend, he should score well once more at a track that rewards strong performances in Saturday's final session.

It's been a testing few weeks for Fernando Alonso owners in F1 Fantasy – three retirements from Monza to Las Vegas, in addition to a season-high 30 points in Singapore.

The Spaniard now heads to a circuit where he has encouraging history. He's finished in the top seven in his three Grand Prix appearances at Lusail, including a podium with Alpine in 2021.

Now priced at $4.5m, the veteran racer cannot fall any further in fantasy value and poses as a budget-friendly option in a week many players will be targeting the likes of Norris and Verstappen for the 3X DRS Boost chip.

The Aston Martin journeyman has the second best averaging Qualifying position this season (10.7) among drivers under $15m, and will be willing the car towards another strong result in Qatar this weekend.

Other drivers to monitor: Oscar Piastri, Nico Hulkenberg

The double disqualification in Las Vegas might understandably deter many new and existing suitors for McLaren in F1 Fantasy – but it is not all bad news.

McLaren have been the highest-scoring F1 Fantasy constructor in each of the last two visits to Qatar, and they're the hot favourites to repeat this feat once more.

The MCL39 has excelled in medium to high-speed corners this season, with the team posting victories at tracks exhibiting similar characteristics, such as Bahrain, Silverstone and Zandvoort.

Expect both drivers to be in the mix to return the team to winning ways this weekend after a disappointing, albeit unexpected, result in Las Vegas.

A double podium in Las Vegas was the cornerstone for another superb Mercedes performance in F1 Fantasy.

The Silver Arrows were once again at their best in Sin City, turning in 77 points on the back of a mesmeric drive from Kimi Antonelli ($17.5m) into the podium positions from P17 and a George Russell ($23.6m) P2 result.

The Brackley team also reeled in an additional 10 fantasy points from a 2.08 second pit stop – their second consecutive week recording double-digit points from their pit box efficiency.

With many routes to fantasy points at an economical price point relative to production, Mercedes continue to represent exceptional value towards the top of the Teams' standings.

Other constructors to monitor: Red Bull, Racing Bulls

3X DRS Boost is an optimal chip to deploy on Sprint weekends. With the fantasy deadline at the start of the Sprint itself, this provides an additional session of point-scoring opportunities for your team.

Utilising this chip on two consistent drivers in high-performing teams (Verstappen and Norris, for example) will ensure you can extract the most value out of it when activated.

As always, be sure to keep a close eye on the earlier sessions to help guide your decisions in the lead up to the team lock deadline.
